qTextArr: ['You were going to say      ?']
qText: You were going to say      ?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr:
["Oh, this fellow! He turned up from nowhere, on the pretext of being a
second cousin or something of Evie's, though she didn't seem
particularly keen to acknowledge the relationship. The fellow is an
absolute outsider, anyone can see that. He's got a great black beard,
and wears patent leather boots in all weathers! But the mater cottoned
to him at once, took him on as secretary   you know how she's always
running a hundred societies?"]
qText:
Oh, this fellow! He turned up from nowhere, on the pretext of being a
second cousin or something of Evie's, though she didn't seem
particularly keen to acknowledge the relationship. The fellow is an
absolute outsider, anyone can see that. He's got a great black beard,
and wears patent leather boots in all weathers! But the mater cottoned
to him at once, took him on as secretary   you know how she's always
running a hundred societies?

qTextArr:
["Well, of course the war has turned the hundreds into thousands. No
doubt the fellow was very useful to her. But you could have knocked us
all down with a feather when, three months ago, she suddenly announced
that she and Alfred were engaged! The fellow must be at least twenty
years younger than she is! It's simply bare-faced fortune hunting; but
there you are   she is her own mistress, and she's married him."]

all down with a feather when, three months ago, she suddenly announced
that she and Alfred were engaged! The fellow must be at least twenty
years younger than she is! It's simply bare-faced fortune hunting; but
there you are   she is her own mistress, and she's married him.

qText: I'm afraid you'll find it very quiet down here, Hastings.

qText: My dear fellow, that's just what I want.

qTextArr:
["Oh, it's pleasant enough if you want to lead the idle life. I drill
with the volunteers twice a week, and lend a hand at the farms. My wife
works regularly    on the land'. She is up at five every morning to milk,
and keeps at it steadily until lunchtime. It's a jolly good life taking
it all round   if it weren't for that fellow Alfred Inglethorp!"]
qText:
Oh, it's pleasant enough if you want to lead the idle life. I drill
with the volunteers twice a week, and lend a hand at the farms. My wife
works regularly    on the land'. She is up at five every morning to milk,
and keeps at it steadily until lunchtime. It's a jolly good life taking
it all round   if it weren't for that fellow Alfred Inglethorp!
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ["I wonder if we've\ntime to pick up Cynthia. No, she'll have started from the hospital by\nnow."]

qTextArr: ["Cynthia! That's not your wife?"]

qTextArr:
["No, Cynthia is a prot  g  e of my mother's, the daughter of an old
schoolfellow of hers, who married a rascally solicitor. He came a
cropper, and the girl was left an orphan and penniless. My mother came
to the rescue, and Cynthia has been with us nearly two years now. She
works in the Red Cross Hospital at Tadminster, seven miles away."]

Duchess   about the school f  te."]
qText:

Lady Tadminster for the second day, myself. Or shall we wait until we

open it the first day, and Mrs. Crosbie the second. Then there's the

qTextArr: ["Well, I've always had a secret hankering to be a detective!"]
qText: Well, I've always had a secret hankering to be a detective!

qTextArr: ['The real thing   Scotland Yard? Or Sherlock Holmes?']
qText: The real thing   Scotland Yard? Or Sherlock Holmes?
speaker: Mary Cavendish

qTextArr:
['Oh, Sherlock Holmes by all means. But really, seriously, I am awfully
drawn to it. I came across a man in Belgium once, a very famous
detective, and he quite inflamed me. He was a marvellous little fellow.
He used to say that all good detective work was a mere matter of
method. My system is based on his   though of course I have progressed
rather further. He was a funny little man, a great dandy, but
wonderfully clever.']
qText:
Oh, Sherlock Holmes by all means. But really, seriously, I am awfully
drawn to it. I came across a man in Belgium once, a very famous
detective, and he quite inflamed me. He was a marvellous little fellow.
He used to say that all good detective work was a mere matter of
method. My system is based on his   though of course I have progressed
rather further. He was a funny little man, a great dandy, but
wonderfully clever.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

Like a good detective story myself, Lots of

qTextArr: ["Don't mean the police, but the people that are right in it. The\nfamily. You couldn't really hoodwink them. They'd know."]
qText:
Don't mean the police, but the people that are right in it. The
family. You couldn't really hoodwink them. They'd know.
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr: ['Then,', "you think that if you were mixed up in a\ncrime, say a murder, you'd be able to spot the murderer right off?"]
qText:
Then, you think that if you were mixed up in a
crime, say a murder, you'd be able to spot the murderer right off?

qTextArr: ["Of course I should. Mightn't be able to prove it to a pack of lawyers.\nBut I'm certain I'd know. I'd feel it in my fingertips if he came near\nme."]
qText:
Of course I should. Mightn't be able to prove it to a pack of lawyers.
But I'm certain I'd know. I'd feel it in my fingertips if he came near
me.
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr:
["John will show you your room. Supper is at half-past seven. We have
given up late dinner for some time now. Lady Tadminster, our Member's
wife   she was the late Lord Abbotsbury's daughter   does the same. She
agrees with me that one must set an example of economy. We are quite a
war household; nothing is wasted here   every scrap of waste paper, even,
is saved and sent away in sacks."]
qText:

sharks   all of them. Oh, I know what I'm talking about. There isn't one

protected her as much as I could. Now I'm out of the way, they'll
impose upon her."]

sharks   all of them. Oh, I know what I'm talking about. There isn't one

qText:
Yes, indeed, I know Mademoiselle Cynthia. It
is by the charity of that good Mrs. Inglethorp that I am here. Yes, my friend, she had kindly
extended hospitality to seven of my countrypeople who, alas, are
refugees from their native land. We Belgians will always remember her
with gratitude.

qTextArr:
["We must try and break the door in, I suppose. It'll be a tough job,

Half a moment, though, isn't there a door into Miss Cynthia's rooms?"]
qText:
We must try and break the door in, I suppose. It'll be a tough job,
though. Here, let one of the maids go down and wake Baily and tell him
to go for Dr. Wilkins at once. Now then, we'll have a try at the door.
Half a moment, though, isn't there a door into Miss Cynthia's rooms?
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr:
['Rubbish!', "In my opinion the whole thing is a
mare's nest of Bauerstein's! Wilkins hadn't an idea of such a thing,
until Bauerstein put it into his head. But, like all specialists,
Bauerstein's got a bee in his bonnet. Poisons are his hobby, so of
course he sees them everywhere."]
qText:
Rubbish! In my opinion the whole thing is a
mare's nest of Bauerstein's! Wilkins hadn't an idea of such a thing,
until Bauerstein put it into his head. But, like all specialists,
Bauerstein's got a bee in his bonnet. Poisons are his hobby, so of
course he sees them everywhere.
speaker: Mr. Lawrence Cavendish

qTextArr: ["I can't feel as you do, Lawrence,", "I'm inclined to\ngive Hastings a free hand, though I should prefer to wait a bit. We\ndon't want any unnecessary scandal."]

give Hastings a free hand, though I should prefer to wait a bit. We
don't want any unnecessary scandal.

No, no, you need have no fear of that. Poirot is

qText:
I do not mind telling you   though, as you know, it is not my habit to
explain until the end is reached. The present contention is that Mrs.
Inglethorp died of strychnine poisoning, presumably administered in her
coffee.

qText: About eight o'clock.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr:
["Therefore she drank it between then and half-past eight   certainly not
much later. Well, strychnine is a fairly rapid poison. Its effects
would be felt very soon, probably in about an hour. Yet, in Mrs.
Inglethorp's case, the symptoms do not manifest themselves until five
o'clock the next morning: nine hours! But a heavy meal, taken at about
the same time as the poison, might retard its effects, though hardly to
that extent. Still, it is a possibility to be taken into account. But,
according to you, she ate very little for supper, and yet the symptoms
do not develop until early the next morning! Now that is a curious
circumstance, my friend. Something may arise at the autopsy to explain
it. In the meantime, remember it."]
qText:
Therefore she drank it between then and half-past eight   certainly not
much later. Well, strychnine is a fairly rapid poison. Its effects
would be felt very soon, probably in about an hour. Yet, in Mrs.
Inglethorp's case, the symptoms do not manifest themselves until five
o'clock the next morning: nine hours! But a heavy meal, taken at about
the same time as the poison, might retard its effects, though hardly to
that extent. Still, it is a possibility to be taken into account. But,
according to you, she ate very little for supper, and yet the symptoms
do not develop until early the next morning! Now that is a curious
circumstance, my friend. Something may arise at the autopsy to explain
it. In the meantime, remember it.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Now, as to this quarrel? What is the first you heard of it?']
qText: Now, as to this quarrel? What is the first you heard of it?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Well, sir, I happened to be going along the hall outside yesterday']
qText: Well, sir, I happened to be going along the hall outside yesterday
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['What time was that?']
qText: What time was that?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
["I couldn't say exactly, sir, but it wasn't tea-time by a long way.
Perhaps four o'clock   or it may have been a bit later. Well, sir, as I
said, I happened to be passing along, when I heard voices very loud and
angry in here. I didn't exactly mean to listen, but   well, there it is.
I stopped. The door was shut, but the mistress was speaking very sharp
and clear, and I heard what she said quite plainly."]
qText:
I couldn't say exactly, sir, but it wasn't tea-time by a long way.
Perhaps four o'clock   or it may have been a bit later. Well, sir, as I
said, I happened to be passing along, when I heard voices very loud and
angry in here. I didn't exactly mean to listen, but   well, there it is.
I stopped. The door was shut, but the mistress was speaking very sharp
and clear, and I heard what she said quite plainly.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ["she said. I didn't hear what Mr. Inglethorp\nreplied. He spoke a good bit lower than she did   but she answered:"]
qText:
she said. I didn't hear what Mr. Inglethorp
replied. He spoke a good bit lower than she did   but she answered:
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ["Again I didn't hear what he said, but she went on:"]
qText: Again I didn't hear what he said, but she went on:
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Then I\nthought I heard them coming out, so I went off quickly.']
qText:
Then I
thought I heard them coming out, so I went off quickly.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ["You are sure it was Mr. Inglethorp's voice you heard?"]
qText: You are sure it was Mr. Inglethorp's voice you heard?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["Oh, yes, sir, whose else's could it be?"]
qText: Oh, yes, sir, whose else's could it be?
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Well, what happened next?']
qText: Well, what happened next?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
["Later, I came back to the hall; but it was all quiet. At five o'clock,
Mrs. Inglethorp rang the bell and told me to bring her a cup of
tea   nothing to eat   to the boudoir. She was looking dreadful   so white
and upset."]
qText:
Later, I came back to the hall; but it was all quiet. At five o'clock,
Mrs. Inglethorp rang the bell and told me to bring her a cup of
tea   nothing to eat   to the boudoir. She was looking dreadful   so white
and upset.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['she says,']
qText: she says,
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['I says.']
qText: I says.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr:
["She had something in her hand. I don't know if it was a letter,
or just a piece of paper, but it had writing on it, and she kept
staring at it, almost as if she couldn't believe what was written
there. She whispered to herself, as though she had forgotten I was
there:"]
qText:
She had something in her hand. I don't know if it was a letter,
or just a piece of paper, but it had writing on it, and she kept
staring at it, almost as if she couldn't believe what was written
there. She whispered to herself, as though she had forgotten I was
there:
speaker: Dorcas
menEnts: [[['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]]

qTextArr: ['And then she says to\nme:']
qText:
And then she says to
me:
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ["I hurried off,\nand got her a good strong cup of tea, and she thanked me, and said\nshe'd feel better when she'd drunk it."]
qText:
I hurried off,
and got her a good strong cup of tea, and she thanked me, and said
she'd feel better when she'd drunk it.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['she\nsays.']
qText:
she
says.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ["Mrs. Cavendish came in just then, so\nshe didn't say any more."]
qText:
Mrs. Cavendish came in just then, so
she didn't say any more.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['She still had the letter, or whatever it was, in her hand?']
qText: She still had the letter, or whatever it was, in her hand?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir.']
qText: Yes, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['What would she be likely to do with it afterwards?']
qText: What would she be likely to do with it afterwards?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["Well, I don't know, sir, I expect she would lock it up in that purple\ncase of hers."]
qText:
Well, I don't know, sir, I expect she would lock it up in that purple
case of hers.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Is that where she usually kept important papers?']
qText: Is that where she usually kept important papers?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir. She brought it down with her every morning, and took it up\nevery night.']
qText:
Yes, sir. She brought it down with her every morning, and took it up
every night.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['When did she lose the key of it?']
qText: When did she lose the key of it?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['She missed it yesterday at lunch-time, sir, and told me to look\ncarefully for it. She was very much put out about it.']
qText:
She missed it yesterday at lunch-time, sir, and told me to look
carefully for it. She was very much put out about it.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['But she had a duplicate key?']
qText: But she had a duplicate key?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Oh, yes, sir.']
qText: Oh, yes, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Never mind, Dorcas, it is my business to know things. Is this the key\nthat was lost?']
qText:
Never mind, Dorcas, it is my business to know things. Is this the key
that was lost?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["That's it, sir, right enough. But where did you find it? I looked\neverywhere for it."]
qText:
That's it, sir, right enough. But where did you find it? I looked
everywhere for it.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Ah, but you see it was not in the same place yesterday as it was\nto-day. Now, to pass to another subject, had your mistress a dark green\ndress in her wardrobe?']
qText:
Ah, but you see it was not in the same place yesterday as it was
to-day. Now, to pass to another subject, had your mistress a dark green
dress in her wardrobe?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['No, sir.']
qText: No, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Are you quite sure?']
qText: Are you quite sure?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Oh, yes, sir.']
qText: Oh, yes, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Has anyone else in the house got a green dress?']
qText: Has anyone else in the house got a green dress?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Miss Cynthia has a green evening dress.']
qText: Miss Cynthia has a green evening dress.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Light or dark green?']
qText: Light or dark green?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['A light green, sir; a sort of chiffon, they call it.']
qText: A light green, sir; a sort of chiffon, they call it.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Ah, that is not what I want. And nobody else has anything green?']
qText: Ah, that is not what I want. And nobody else has anything green?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['No, sir   not that I know of.']
qText: No, sir   not that I know of.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Good, we will leave that and pass on. Have you any reason to believe\nthat your mistress was likely to take a sleeping powder last night?']
qText:
Good, we will leave that and pass on. Have you any reason to believe
that your mistress was likely to take a sleeping powder last night?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["Not _last_ night, sir, I know she didn't."]
qText: Not _last_ night, sir, I know she didn't.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Why do you know so positively?']
qText: Why do you know so positively?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["Because the box was empty. She took the last one two days ago, and she\ndidn't have any more made up."]
qText:
Because the box was empty. She took the last one two days ago, and she
didn't have any more made up.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['You are quite sure of that?']
qText: You are quite sure of that?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Positive, sir.']
qText: Positive, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ["Then that is cleared up! By the way, your mistress didn't ask you to\nsign any paper yesterday?"]
qText:
Then that is cleared up! By the way, your mistress didn't ask you to
sign any paper yesterday?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['To sign a paper? No, sir.']
qText: To sign a paper? No, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['When Mr. Hastings and Mr. Lawrence came in yesterday evening, they\nfound your mistress busy writing letters. I suppose you can give me no\nidea to whom these letters were addressed?']
qText:
When Mr. Hastings and Mr. Lawrence came in yesterday evening, they
found your mistress busy writing letters. I suppose you can give me no
idea to whom these letters were addressed?
speaker: Hercule Poirot
menEnts: [[['Mr. Hastings'], ['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Dorcas']]]

qTextArr:
["I'm afraid I couldn't, sir. I was out in the evening. Perhaps Annie
could tell you, though she's a careless girl. Never cleared the
coffee-cups away last night. That's what happens when I'm not here to
look after things."]
qText:
I'm afraid I couldn't, sir. I was out in the evening. Perhaps Annie
could tell you, though she's a careless girl. Never cleared the
coffee-cups away last night. That's what happens when I'm not here to
look after things.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Since they have been left, Dorcas, leave them a little longer, I pray\nyou. I should like to examine them.']
qText:
Since they have been left, Dorcas, leave them a little longer, I pray
you. I should like to examine them.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Very well, sir.']
qText: Very well, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['What time did you go out last evening?']
qText: What time did you go out last evening?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["About six o'clock, sir."]
qText: About six o'clock, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Thank you, Dorcas, that is all I have to ask you.']
qText: Thank you, Dorcas, that is all I have to ask you.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['I have been admiring these flower beds. How\nmany gardeners are employed here, by the way?']
qText:
I have been admiring these flower beds. How
many gardeners are employed here, by the way?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
["Only three now, sir. Five, we had, before the war, when it was kept as
a gentleman's place should be. I wish you could have seen it then, sir.
A fair sight it was. But now there's only old Manning, and young
William, and a new-fashioned woman gardener in breeches and such-like.
Ah, these are dreadful times!"]
qText:
Only three now, sir. Five, we had, before the war, when it was kept as
a gentleman's place should be. I wish you could have seen it then, sir.
A fair sight it was. But now there's only old Manning, and young
William, and a new-fashioned woman gardener in breeches and such-like.
Ah, these are dreadful times!
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['The good times will come again, Dorcas. At least, we hope so. Now,\nwill you send Annie to me here?']
qText:
The good times will come again, Dorcas. At least, we hope so. Now,
will you send Annie to me here?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir. Thank you, sir.']
qText: Yes, sir. Thank you, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['How did you know that Mrs. Inglethorp took sleeping powders?', 'And about the lost key\nand the duplicate?']
qText:
How did you know that Mrs. Inglethorp took sleeping powders? And about the lost key
and the duplicate?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['One thing at a time. As to the sleeping powders, I knew by this.']
qText: One thing at a time. As to the sleeping powders, I knew by this.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Where did you find it?']
qText: Where did you find it?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ["In the wash-stand drawer in Mrs. Inglethorp's bedroom. It was Number\nSix of my catalogue."]
qText:
In the wash-stand drawer in Mrs. Inglethorp's bedroom. It was Number
Six of my catalogue.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['But I suppose, as the last powder was taken two days ago, it is not of\nmuch importance?']
qText:
But I suppose, as the last powder was taken two days ago, it is not of
much importance?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['Probably not, but do you notice anything that strikes you as peculiar\nabout this box?']
qText:
Probably not, but do you notice anything that strikes you as peculiar
about this box?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["No, I can't say that I do."]
qText: No, I can't say that I do.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['Look at the label.']
qText: Look at the label.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['No, I see nothing unusual.']
qText: No, I see nothing unusual.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ["Not the fact that there is no chemist's name?"]
qText: Not the fact that there is no chemist's name?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Ah!', 'To be sure, that is odd!']
qText: Ah! To be sure, that is odd!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['Have you ever known a chemist to send out a box like that, without his\nprinted name?']
qText:
Have you ever known a chemist to send out a box like that, without his
printed name?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["No, I can't say that I have."]
qText: No, I can't say that I have.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['Yet the explanation is quite simple. So do not intrigue yourself, my\nfriend.']
qText:
Yet the explanation is quite simple. So do not intrigue yourself, my
friend.
speaker: Hercule Poirot
refExp: Poirot damped my ardour by remarking

qTextArr: ['I sent for you, Annie, because I thought you might be able to tell me\nsomething about the letters Mrs. Inglethorp wrote last night. How many\nwere there? And can you tell me any of the names and addresses?']
qText:
I sent for you, Annie, because I thought you might be able to tell me
something about the letters Mrs. Inglethorp wrote last night. How many
were there? And can you tell me any of the names and addresses?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
["There were four letters, sir. One was to Miss Howard, and one was to
Mr. Wells, the lawyer, and the other two I don't think I remember,
sir   oh, yes, one was to Ross's, the caterers in Tadminster. The other
one, I don't remember."]
qText:
There were four letters, sir. One was to Miss Howard, and one was to
Mr. Wells, the lawyer, and the other two I don't think I remember,
sir   oh, yes, one was to Ross's, the caterers in Tadminster. The other
one, I don't remember.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['Think,']
qText: Think,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["I'm sorry, sir, but it's clean gone. I don't think I can have noticed\nit."]
qText:
I'm sorry, sir, but it's clean gone. I don't think I can have noticed
it.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['It does not matter,', "Now I want to ask you about something else. There is a\nsaucepan in Mrs. Inglethorp's room with some cocoa in it. Did she have\nthat every night?"]
qText:
It does not matter, Now I want to ask you about something else. There is a
saucepan in Mrs. Inglethorp's room with some cocoa in it. Did she have
that every night?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir, it was put in her room every evening, and she warmed it up\nin the night   whenever she fancied it.']
qText:
Yes, sir, it was put in her room every evening, and she warmed it up
in the night   whenever she fancied it.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['What was it? Plain cocoa?']
qText: What was it? Plain cocoa?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir, made with milk, with a teaspoonful of sugar, and two\nteaspoonfuls of rum in it.']
qText:
Yes, sir, made with milk, with a teaspoonful of sugar, and two
teaspoonfuls of rum in it.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['Who took it to her room?']
qText: Who took it to her room?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['I did, sir.']
qText: I did, sir.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['Always?']
qText: Always?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir.']
qText: Yes, sir.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['At what time?']
qText: At what time?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['When I went to draw the curtains, as a rule, sir.']
qText: When I went to draw the curtains, as a rule, sir.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['Did you bring it straight up from the kitchen then?']
qText: Did you bring it straight up from the kitchen then?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
["No, sir, you see there's not much room on the gas stove, so cook used
to make it early, before putting the vegetables on for supper. Then I
used to bring it up, and put it on the table by the swing door, and
take it into her room later."]
qText:
No, sir, you see there's not much room on the gas stove, so cook used
to make it early, before putting the vegetables on for supper. Then I
used to bring it up, and put it on the table by the swing door, and
take it into her room later.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['The swing door is in the left wing, is it not?']
qText: The swing door is in the left wing, is it not?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir.']
qText: Yes, sir.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ["And the table, is it on this side of the door, or on the\nfarther   servants' side?"]
qText:
And the table, is it on this side of the door, or on the
farther   servants' side?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["It's this side, sir."]
qText: It's this side, sir.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['What time did you bring it up last night?']
qText: What time did you bring it up last night?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['About quarter-past seven, I should say, sir.']
qText: About quarter-past seven, I should say, sir.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ["And when did you take it into Mrs. Inglethorp's room?"]
qText: And when did you take it into Mrs. Inglethorp's room?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["When I went to shut up, sir. About eight o'clock. Mrs. Inglethorp came\nup to bed before I'd finished."]
qText:
When I went to shut up, sir. About eight o'clock. Mrs. Inglethorp came
up to bed before I'd finished.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ["Then, between seven-fifteen and eight o'clock, the cocoa was standing\non the table in the left wing?"]
qText:
Then, between seven-fifteen and eight o'clock, the cocoa was standing
on the table in the left wing?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir.']
qText: Yes, sir.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ["And if there _was_ salt in it, sir, it wasn't me. I never took the\nsalt near it."]
qText:
And if there _was_ salt in it, sir, it wasn't me. I never took the
salt near it.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['What makes you think there was salt in it?']
qText: What makes you think there was salt in it?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Seeing it on the tray, sir.']
qText: Seeing it on the tray, sir.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['You saw some salt on the tray?']
qText: You saw some salt on the tray?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
["Yes. Coarse kitchen salt, it looked. I never noticed it when I took
the tray up, but when I came to take it into the mistress's room I saw
it at once, and I suppose I ought to have taken it down again, and
asked cook to make some fresh. But I was in a hurry, because Dorcas was
out, and I thought maybe the cocoa itself was all right, and the salt
had only gone on the tray. So I dusted it off with my apron, and took
it in."]
qText:
Yes. Coarse kitchen salt, it looked. I never noticed it when I took
the tray up, but when I came to take it into the mistress's room I saw
it at once, and I suppose I ought to have taken it down again, and
asked cook to make some fresh. But I was in a hurry, because Dorcas was
out, and I thought maybe the cocoa itself was all right, and the salt
had only gone on the tray. So I dusted it off with my apron, and took
it in.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ["When you went into Mrs. Inglethorp's room, was the door leading into\nMiss Cynthia's room bolted?"]
qText:
When you went into Mrs. Inglethorp's room, was the door leading into
Miss Cynthia's room bolted?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Oh! Yes, sir; it always was. It had never been opened.']
qText: Oh! Yes, sir; it always was. It had never been opened.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ["And the door into Mr. Inglethorp's room? Did you notice if that was\nbolted too?"]
qText:
And the door into Mr. Inglethorp's room? Did you notice if that was
bolted too?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["I couldn't rightly say, sir; it was shut but I couldn't say whether it\nwas bolted or not."]
qText:
I couldn't rightly say, sir; it was shut but I couldn't say whether it
was bolted or not.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['When you finally left the room, did Mrs. Inglethorp bolt the door\nafter you?']
qText:
When you finally left the room, did Mrs. Inglethorp bolt the door
after you?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['No, sir, not then, but I expect she did later. She usually did lock it\nat night. The door into the passage, that is.']
qText:
No, sir, not then, but I expect she did later. She usually did lock it
at night. The door into the passage, that is.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['Did you notice any candle grease on the floor when you did the room\nyesterday?']
qText:
Did you notice any candle grease on the floor when you did the room
yesterday?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["Candle grease? Oh, no, sir. Mrs. Inglethorp didn't have a candle, only\na reading-lamp."]
qText:
Candle grease? Oh, no, sir. Mrs. Inglethorp didn't have a candle, only
a reading-lamp.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['Then, if there had been a large patch of candle grease on the floor,\nyou think you would have been sure to have seen it?']
qText:
Then, if there had been a large patch of candle grease on the floor,
you think you would have been sure to have seen it?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir, and I would have taken it out with a piece of blotting-paper\nand a hot iron.']
qText:
Yes, sir, and I would have taken it out with a piece of blotting-paper
and a hot iron.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['Did your mistress ever have a green dress?']
qText: Did your mistress ever have a green dress?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['No, sir.']
qText: No, sir.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['Nor a mantle, nor a cape, nor a   how do you call it?   a sports coat?']
qText: Nor a mantle, nor a cape, nor a   how do you call it?   a sports coat?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Not green, sir.']
qText: Not green, sir.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['Nor anyone else in the house?']
qText: Nor anyone else in the house?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['No, sir.']
qText: No, sir.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['You are sure of that?']
qText: You are sure of that?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Quite sure.']
qText: Quite sure.
speaker: Annie

qTextArr: ['_Bien!_ That is all I want to know. Thank you very much.']
qText: _Bien!_ That is all I want to know. Thank you very much.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Poirot,', 'I congratulate you! This is a great discovery.']
qText: Poirot, I congratulate you! This is a great discovery.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['What is a great discovery?']
qText: What is a great discovery?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Why, that it was the cocoa and not the coffee that was poisoned. That\nexplains everything! Of course it did not take effect until the early\nmorning, since the cocoa was only drunk in the middle of the night.']
qText:
Why, that it was the cocoa and not the coffee that was poisoned. That
explains everything! Of course it did not take effect until the early
morning, since the cocoa was only drunk in the middle of the night.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['So you think that the cocoa   mark well what I say, Hastings, the\n_cocoa_   contained strychnine?']
qText:
So you think that the cocoa   mark well what I say, Hastings, the
_cocoa_   contained strychnine?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

It's an awkward position for all of us. Of course one has to treat him

with a possible murderer!

qTextArr:
["I quite understand. It is a very difficult situation for you, Mr.
Cavendish. I would like to ask you one question. Mr. Inglethorp's
reason for not returning last night was, I believe, that he had
forgotten the latch-key. Is not that so?"]
qText:
I quite understand. It is a very difficult situation for you, Mr.
Cavendish. I would like to ask you one question. Mr. Inglethorp's
reason for not returning last night was, I believe, that he had
forgotten the latch-key. Is not that so?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Yes.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['I suppose you are quite sure that the latch-key _was_ forgotten   that\nhe did not take it after all?']
qText:
I suppose you are quite sure that the latch-key _was_ forgotten   that
he did not take it after all?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["I have no idea. I never thought of looking. We always keep it in the\nhall drawer. I'll go and see if it's there now."]
qText:
I have no idea. I never thought of looking. We always keep it in the
hall drawer. I'll go and see if it's there now.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['No, no, Mr. Cavendish, it is too late now. I am certain that you would\nfind it. If Mr. Inglethorp did take it, he has had ample time to\nreplace it by now.']
qText:
No, no, Mr. Cavendish, it is too late now. I am certain that you would
find it. If Mr. Inglethorp did take it, he has had ample time to
replace it by now.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: But do you think
speaker: John Cavendish

return, and seen it there, it would have been a valuable point in his
favour. That is all.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

breakfast.

last will, dated August of last year, after various unimportant

I do not see any reason why I should not answer your question. By her

["No, I do not think so. You see, under the terms of their father's
will, while John inherited the property, Lawrence, at his stepmother's
death, would come into a considerable sum of money. Mrs. Inglethorp
left her money to her elder stepson, knowing that he would have to keep
up Styles. It was, to my mind, a very fair and equitable distribution."]
qText:
No, I do not think so. You see, under the terms of their father's
will, while John inherited the property, Lawrence, at his stepmother's
death, would come into a considerable sum of money. Mrs. Inglethorp

qTextArr: ['I do not think so. In fact I am almost certain that it was made no\nearlier than yesterday afternoon.']
qText:
I do not think so. In fact I am almost certain that it was made no
earlier than yesterday afternoon.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['If you will allow me to send for your gardener, I will prove it to\nyou.']
qText:
If you will allow me to send for your gardener, I will prove it to
you.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["Oh, of course   but I don't see"]
qText: Oh, of course   but I don't see
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['Do as I ask you. Afterwards you shall question as much as you please.']
qText: Do as I ask you. Afterwards you shall question as much as you please.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Very well.']
qText: Very well.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['Dorcas, will you tell Manning to come round and speak to me here.']
qText: Dorcas, will you tell Manning to come round and speak to me here.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir.']
qText: Yes, sir.
speaker: Dorcas

qTextArr: ['Come inside, Manning,', 'I want to speak to you.', 'Manning,', 'this gentleman will put some questions to you\nwhich I want you to answer.']
qText:
Come inside, Manning, I want to speak to you. Manning, this gentleman will put some questions to you
which I want you to answer.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['Yessir,']
qText: Yessir,
speaker: Manning

qTextArr: ['You were planting a bed of begonias round by the south side of the\nhouse yesterday afternoon, were you not, Manning?']
qText:
You were planting a bed of begonias round by the south side of the
house yesterday afternoon, were you not, Manning?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir, me and Willum.']
qText: Yes, sir, me and Willum.
speaker: Manning

qTextArr: ['And Mrs. Inglethorp came to the window and called you, did she not?']
qText: And Mrs. Inglethorp came to the window and called you, did she not?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir, she did.']
qText: Yes, sir, she did.
speaker: Manning

qTextArr: ['Tell me in your own words exactly what happened after that.']
qText: Tell me in your own words exactly what happened after that.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["Well, sir, nothing much. She just told Willum to go on his bicycle\ndown to the village, and bring back a form of will, or such-like   I\ndon't know what exactly   she wrote it down for him."]
qText:
Well, sir, nothing much. She just told Willum to go on his bicycle
down to the village, and bring back a form of will, or such-like   I
don't know what exactly   she wrote it down for him.
speaker: Manning

qTextArr: ['Well?']
qText: Well?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Well, he did, sir.']
qText: Well, he did, sir.
speaker: Manning

qTextArr: ['And what happened next?']
qText: And what happened next?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['We went on with the begonias, sir.']
qText: We went on with the begonias, sir.
speaker: Manning

qTextArr: ['Did not Mrs. Inglethorp call you again?']
qText: Did not Mrs. Inglethorp call you again?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir, both me and Willum, she called.']
qText: Yes, sir, both me and Willum, she called.
speaker: Manning

qTextArr: ['And then?']
qText: And then?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["She made us come right in, and sign our names at the bottom of a long\npaper   under where she'd signed."]
qText:
She made us come right in, and sign our names at the bottom of a long
paper   under where she'd signed.
speaker: Manning

qTextArr: ['Did you see anything of what was written above her signature?']
qText: Did you see anything of what was written above her signature?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['No, sir, there was a bit of blotting paper over that part.']
qText: No, sir, there was a bit of blotting paper over that part.
speaker: Manning

qTextArr: ['And you signed where she told you?']
qText: And you signed where she told you?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, sir, first me and then Willum.']
qText: Yes, sir, first me and then Willum.
speaker: Manning

qTextArr: ['What did she do with it afterwards?']
qText: What did she do with it afterwards?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Well, sir, she slipped it into a long envelope, and put it inside a\nsort of purple box that was standing on the desk.']
qText:
Well, sir, she slipped it into a long envelope, and put it inside a
sort of purple box that was standing on the desk.
speaker: Manning

qTextArr: ['What time was it when she first called you?']
qText: What time was it when she first called you?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['About four, I should say, sir.']
qText: About four, I should say, sir.
speaker: Manning

qTextArr: ["Not earlier? Couldn't it have been about half-past three?"]
qText: Not earlier? Couldn't it have been about half-past three?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["No, I shouldn't say so, sir. It would be more likely to be a bit after\nfour   not before it."]
qText:
No, I shouldn't say so, sir. It would be more likely to be a bit after
four   not before it.
speaker: Manning

qTextArr: ['Thank you, Manning, that will do,']
qText: Thank you, Manning, that will do,
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Good heavens!', 'What an extraordinary coincidence.']
qText: Good heavens! What an extraordinary coincidence.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['How   a coincidence?']
qText: How   a coincidence?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['That my mother should have made a will on the very day of her death!']
qText: That my mother should have made a will on the very day of her death!
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['Are you so sure it is a coincidence, Cavendish?']
qText: Are you so sure it is a coincidence, Cavendish?
speaker: Mr. Wells
refExp: Mr Wells cleared his throat and remarked

qTextArr: ['What do you mean?']
qText: What do you mean?
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['Your mother, you tell me, had a violent quarrel with   someone yesterday\nafternoon']
qText:
Your mother, you tell me, had a violent quarrel with   someone yesterday
afternoon
speaker: Mr. Wells

qTextArr: ['What do you mean?']
qText: What do you mean?
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr:
['In consequence of that quarrel, your mother very suddenly and
hurriedly makes a new will. The contents of that will we shall never
know. She told no one of its provisions. This morning, no doubt, she
would have consulted me on the subject   but she had no chance. The will
disappears, and she takes its secret with her to her grave. Cavendish,
I much fear there is no coincidence there. Monsieur Poirot, I am sure
you agree with me that the facts are very suggestive.']
qText:
In consequence of that quarrel, your mother very suddenly and
hurriedly makes a new will. The contents of that will we shall never
know. She told no one of its provisions. This morning, no doubt, she
would have consulted me on the subject   but she had no chance. The will
disappears, and she takes its secret with her to her grave. Cavendish,
I much fear there is no coincidence there. Monsieur Poirot, I am sure
you agree with me that the facts are very suggestive.
speaker: Mr. Wells
menEnts: [[['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Hercule Poirot', 'John Cavendish', 'Mr. Wells', 'Mr. Hastings'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Hercule Poirot']]]

qTextArr:
['Suggestive, or not,', 'we are most grateful to
Monsieur Poirot for elucidating the matter. But for him, we should
never have known of this will. I suppose, I may not ask you, monsieur,
what first led you to suspect the fact?']
qText:
Suggestive, or not, we are most grateful to
Monsieur Poirot for elucidating the matter. But for him, we should
never have known of this will. I suppose, I may not ask you, monsieur,
what first led you to suspect the fact?
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: A scribbled over old envelope, and a freshly planted bed of begonias.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Evie!', 'Excuse me, Wells.']
qText: Evie! Excuse me, Wells.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['Miss Howard,']
qText: Miss Howard,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['Ah, I am glad she has come. There is a woman with a head and a heart\ntoo, Hastings. Though the good God gave her no beauty!']
qText:
Ah, I am glad she has come. There is a woman with a head and a heart
too, Hastings. Though the good God gave her no beauty!
speaker: Hercule Poirot
menTexts: [['she', 'a woman with a head and a heart\ntoo', 'Hastings', 'her']]

qTextArr: ['Started the moment I got the wire. Just come off night duty. Hired\ncar. Quickest way to get here.']
qText:
Started the moment I got the wire. Just come off night duty. Hired
car. Quickest way to get here.
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr: ['Have you had anything to eat this morning, Evie?']
qText: Have you had anything to eat this morning, Evie?
speaker: John Cavendish

qText: No.
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr: ["I thought not. Come along, breakfast's not cleared away yet, and\nthey'll make you some fresh tea."]
qText:
I thought not. Come along, breakfast's not cleared away yet, and
they'll make you some fresh tea.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ["Look after her,\nHastings, will you? Wells is waiting for me. Oh, here's Monsieur\nPoirot. He's helping us, you know, Evie."]
qText:
Look after her,
Hastings, will you? Wells is waiting for me. Oh, here's Monsieur
Poirot. He's helping us, you know, Evie.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['What do you mean   helping us?']
qText: What do you mean   helping us?
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr: ['Helping us to investigate.']
qText: Helping us to investigate.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['Nothing to investigate. Have they taken him to prison yet?']
qText: Nothing to investigate. Have they taken him to prison yet?
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr: ['Taken who to prison?']
qText: Taken who to prison?
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['Who? Alfred Inglethorp, of course!']
qText: Who? Alfred Inglethorp, of course!
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr: ['My dear Evie, do be careful. Lawrence is of the opinion that my mother\ndied from heart seizure.']
qText:
My dear Evie, do be careful. Lawrence is of the opinion that my mother
died from heart seizure.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['More fool, Lawrence!', 'Of course Alfred\nInglethorp murdered poor Emily   as I always told you he would.']
qText:
More fool, Lawrence! Of course Alfred
Inglethorp murdered poor Emily   as I always told you he would.
speaker: Evelyn Howard
menEnts: [[['Mr. Lawrence Cavendish']], [['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['John Cavendish'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]]

qTextArr: ["My dear Evie, don't shout so. Whatever we may think or suspect, it is\nbetter to say as little as possible for the present. The inquest isn't\nuntil Friday."]
qText:
My dear Evie, don't shout so. Whatever we may think or suspect, it is
better to say as little as possible for the present. The inquest isn't
until Friday.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['Not until fiddlesticks!']
qText: Not until fiddlesticks!
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr: ["You're all off your heads. The man will be out of the\ncountry by then. If he's any sense, he won't stay here tamely and wait\nto be hanged."]
qText:
You're all off your heads. The man will be out of the
country by then. If he's any sense, he won't stay here tamely and wait
to be hanged.
speaker: Evelyn Howard
menEnts: [[['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['John Cavendish', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mr. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]]

qTextArr:
['I know what it is,', "you've been listening to the
doctors. Never should. What do they know? Nothing at all   or just enough
to make them dangerous. I ought to know   my own father was a doctor.
That little Wilkins is about the greatest fool that even I have ever
seen. Heart seizure! Sort of thing he would say. Anyone with any sense
could see at once that her husband had poisoned her. I always said he'd
murder her in her bed, poor soul. Now he's done it. And all you can do
is to murmur silly things about", 'and', 'You ought to be ashamed of yourself, John Cavendish.']
qText:
I know what it is, you've been listening to the
doctors. Never should. What do they know? Nothing at all   or just enough
to make them dangerous. I ought to know   my own father was a doctor.
That little Wilkins is about the greatest fool that even I have ever
seen. Heart seizure! Sort of thing he would say. Anyone with any sense
could see at once that her husband had poisoned her. I always said he'd
murder her in her bed, poor soul. Now he's done it. And all you can do
is to murmur silly things about and You ought to be ashamed of yourself, John Cavendish.
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr: ['What do you want me to do?', "Dash it all, Evie, I can't haul him down to the local police station\nby the scruff of his neck."]
qText:
What do you want me to do? Dash it all, Evie, I can't haul him down to the local police station
by the scruff of his neck.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ["Well, you might do something. Find out how he did it. He's a crafty\nbeggar. Dare say he soaked fly papers. Ask cook if she's missed any."]
qText:
Well, you might do something. Find out how he did it. He's a crafty
beggar. Dare say he soaked fly papers. Ask cook if she's missed any.
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr: ['Mademoiselle,', 'I want to ask you something.']
qText: Mademoiselle, I want to ask you something.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Ask away,']
qText: Ask away,
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr: ['I want to be able to count upon your help.']
qText: I want to be able to count upon your help.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["I'll help you to hang Alfred with pleasure,", "Hanging's too good for him. Ought to be drawn and quartered, like in\ngood old times."]
qText:
I'll help you to hang Alfred with pleasure, Hanging's too good for him. Ought to be drawn and quartered, like in
good old times.
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr: ['We are at one then,', 'for I, too, want to hang the\ncriminal.']
qText:
We are at one then, for I, too, want to hang the
criminal.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Alfred Inglethorp?']
qText: Alfred Inglethorp?
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr: ['Him, or another.']
qText: Him, or another.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
["No question of another. Poor Emily was never murdered until _he_ came
along. I don't say she wasn't surrounded by sharks   she was. But it was
only her purse they were after. Her life was safe enough. But along
comes Mr. Alfred Inglethorp   and within two months   hey presto!"]
qText:
No question of another. Poor Emily was never murdered until _he_ came
along. I don't say she wasn't surrounded by sharks   she was. But it was
only her purse they were after. Her life was safe enough. But along
comes Mr. Alfred Inglethorp   and within two months   hey presto!
speaker: Evelyn Howard
menEnts: [[['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['John Cavendish', 'Mary Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]]

qTextArr: ['Believe me, Miss Howard,', 'if Mr.\nInglethorp is the man, he shall not escape me. On my honour, I will\nhang him as high as Haman!']
qText:
Believe me, Miss Howard, if Mr.
Inglethorp is the man, he shall not escape me. On my honour, I will
hang him as high as Haman!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["That's better,"]
qText: That's better,
speaker: Evelyn Howard

qTextArr: ['But I must ask you to trust me. Now your help may be very valuable to\nme. I will tell you why. Because, in all this house of mourning, yours\nare the only eyes that have wept.']
qText:
But I must ask you to trust me. Now your help may be very valuable to
me. I will tell you why. Because, in all this house of mourning, yours
are the only eyes that have wept.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
["If you mean that I was fond of her   yes, I was. You know, Emily was a
selfish old woman in her way. She was very generous, but she always
wanted a return. She never let people forget what she had done for
them   and, that way she missed love. Don't think she ever realized it,
though, or felt the lack of it. Hope not, anyway. I was on a different
footing. I took my stand from the first."]
qText:
If you mean that I was fond of her   yes, I was. You know, Emily was a
selfish old woman in her way. She was very generous, but she always
wanted a return. She never let people forget what she had done for
them   and, that way she missed love. Don't think she ever realized it,
though, or felt the lack of it. Hope not, anyway. I was on a different
footing. I took my stand from the first.
speaker: Evelyn Howard
menEnts: [[['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Hercule Poirot'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp']]]

qTextArr:
["She didn't understand   was very
offended sometimes. Said I was foolishly proud. It wasn't that   but I
couldn't explain. Anyway, I kept my self-respect. And so, out of the
whole bunch, I was the only one who could allow myself to be fond of
her. I watched over her. I guarded her from the lot of them, and then a
glib-tongued scoundrel comes along, and pooh! all my years of devotion
go for nothing."]
qText:
She didn't understand   was very
offended sometimes. Said I was foolishly proud. It wasn't that   but I
couldn't explain. Anyway, I kept my self-respect. And so, out of the
whole bunch, I was the only one who could allow myself to be fond of
her. I watched over her. I guarded her from the lot of them, and then a
glib-tongued scoundrel comes along, and pooh! all my years of devotion
go for nothing.
speaker: Evelyn Howard
menEnts: [[['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Mary Cavendish', 'John Cavendish', 'Miss Murdoch', 'Mr. Lawrence Cavendish'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]]

qTextArr: ['I understand, mademoiselle, I understand all you feel. It is most\nnatural. You think that we are lukewarm   that we lack fire and\nenergy   but trust me, it is not so.']
qText:
I understand, mademoiselle, I understand all you feel. It is most
natural. You think that we are lukewarm   that we lack fire and
energy   but trust me, it is not so.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: I've told Mary to keep them apart if she can.

qText: Will she be able to do so?

The Lord only knows. There's one thing, Inglethorp himself won't be

qText: You've got the keys still, haven't you, Poirot?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText:
My mother kept most of her important papers in this despatch-case, I
believe,
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['Permit me. I locked it, out of precaution, this morning.']
qText: Permit me. I locked it, out of precaution, this morning.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ["But it's not locked now."]
qText: But it's not locked now.
speaker: John Cavendish

qTextArr: ['Impossible!']
qText: Impossible!

qText: See.

refExp: John lifted the lid as he spoke

qTextArr: ['_Milles tonnerres!_', 'And I   who have both\nthe keys in my pocket!', '_Eh voil   une affaire!_ This lock has been forced.']
qText:
_Milles tonnerres!_ And I   who have both
the keys in my pocket! _Eh voil   une affaire!_ This lock has been forced.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Who? That is the question. Why? Ah, if I only knew. When? Since I was\nhere an hour ago. As to the door being locked, it is a very ordinary\nlock. Probably any other of the doorkeys in this passage would fit it.']
qText:
Who? That is the question. Why? Ah, if I only knew. When? Since I was
here an hour ago. As to the door being locked, it is a very ordinary
lock. Probably any other of the doorkeys in this passage would fit it.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
['See here, it was like this,', 'There was something in
that case   some piece of evidence, slight in itself perhaps, but still
enough of a clue to connect the murderer with the crime. It was vital
to him that it should be destroyed before it was discovered and its
significance appreciated. Therefore, he took the risk, the great risk,
of coming in here. Finding the case locked, he was obliged to force it,
thus betraying his presence. For him to take that risk, it must have
been something of great importance.']
qText:
See here, it was like this, There was something in
that case   some piece of evidence, slight in itself perhaps, but still
enough of a clue to connect the murderer with the crime. It was vital
to him that it should be destroyed before it was discovered and its
significance appreciated. Therefore, he took the risk, the great risk,
of coming in here. Finding the case locked, he was obliged to force it,
thus betraying his presence. For him to take that risk, it must have
been something of great importance.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
['Ah!', 'That, I do not know! A
document of some kind, without doubt, possibly the scrap of paper
Dorcas saw in her hand yesterday afternoon. And I', 'miserable animal that I am! I guessed nothing! I have
behaved like an imbecile! I should never have left that case here. I
should have carried it away with me. Ah, triple pig! And now it is
gone. It is destroyed   but is it destroyed? Is there not yet a chance   we
must leave no stone unturned']
qText:
Ah! That, I do not know! A
document of some kind, without doubt, possibly the scrap of paper
Dorcas saw in her hand yesterday afternoon. And I miserable animal that I am! I guessed nothing! I have
behaved like an imbecile! I should never have left that case here. I
should have carried it away with me. Ah, triple pig! And now it is
gone. It is destroyed   but is it destroyed? Is there not yet a chance   we
must leave no stone unturned
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['What has happened to your extraordinary little friend, Mr. Hastings?\nHe has just rushed past me like a mad bull.']
qText:
What has happened to your extraordinary little friend, Mr. Hastings?
He has just rushed past me like a mad bull.
speaker: Mary Cavendish

qText: He's rather upset about something,

qText: Well, don't you?

flare up. It would clear the air. At present we are all thinking so

Because it is true. I am charming to my friends one day, and forget
all about them the next.

qText: Yet you seem to be invariably charming to Dr. Bauerstein!

qText:
My dear fellow, is this wise? Surely you don't want the

My friend, I have a little idea, a very
strange, and probably utterly impossible idea. And yet   it fits in.

qTextArr: ['So that is the explanation of the blank label on the box,', 'Very simple, as you said. I really wonder that I did not think of it\nmyself.']
qText:
So that is the explanation of the blank label on the box, Very simple, as you said. I really wonder that I did not think of it

qTextArr: ['They have made one more discovery, _l  -bas_,', 'Mr. Wells told me\nas we were going upstairs.']

They have made one more discovery, _l  -bas_, Mr. Wells told me
as we were going upstairs.

qTextArr: ['What was it?']
qText: What was it?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr:
["Locked up in the desk in the boudoir, they found a will of Mrs.
Inglethorp's, dated before her marriage, leaving her fortune to Alfred
Inglethorp. It must have been made just at the time they were engaged.
It came quite as a surprise to Wells   and to John Cavendish also. It was
written on one of those printed will forms, and witnessed by two of the
servants   not Dorcas."]
qText:
Locked up in the desk in the boudoir, they found a will of Mrs.
Inglethorp's, dated before her marriage, leaving her fortune to Alfred
Inglethorp. It must have been made just at the time they were engaged.
It came quite as a surprise to Wells   and to John Cavendish also. It was
written on one of those printed will forms, and witnessed by two of the
servants   not Dorcas.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Did Mr. Inglethorp know of it?']
qText: Did Mr. Inglethorp know of it?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['He says not.']
qText: He says not.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['One might take that with a grain of salt,', 'All these wills are very confusing. Tell me, how did those scribbled\nwords on the envelope help you to discover that a will was made\nyesterday afternoon?']
qText:
One might take that with a grain of salt, All these wills are very confusing. Tell me, how did those scribbled
words on the envelope help you to discover that a will was made
yesterday afternoon?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['_Mon ami_, have you ever, when writing a letter, been arrested by the\nfact that you did not know how to spell a certain word?']
qText:
_Mon ami_, have you ever, when writing a letter, been arrested by the
fact that you did not know how to spell a certain word?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes, often. I suppose everyone has.']
qText: Yes, often. I suppose everyone has.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr:
["Exactly. And have you not, in such a case, tried the word once or
twice on the edge of the blotting-paper, or a spare scrap of paper, to
see if it looked right? Well, that is what Mrs. Inglethorp did. You
will notice that the word    possessed' is spelt first with one    s' and
subsequently with two   correctly. To make sure, she had further tried it
in a sentence, thus:"]
qText:
Exactly. And have you not, in such a case, tried the word once or
twice on the edge of the blotting-paper, or a spare scrap of paper, to
see if it looked right? Well, that is what Mrs. Inglethorp did. You
will notice that the word    possessed' is spelt first with one    s' and
subsequently with two   correctly. To make sure, she had further tried it
in a sentence, thus:
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
["Now, what did that tell me? It
told me that Mrs. Inglethorp had been writing the word    possessed' that
afternoon, and, having the fragment of paper found in the grate fresh
in my mind, the possibility of a will   (a document almost certain to
contain that word)   occurred to me at once. This possibility was
confirmed by a further circumstance. In the general confusion, the
boudoir had not been swept that morning, and near the desk were several
traces of brown mould and earth. The weather had been perfectly fine
for some days, and no ordinary boots would have left such a heavy
deposit."]
qText:
Now, what did that tell me? It
told me that Mrs. Inglethorp had been writing the word    possessed' that
afternoon, and, having the fragment of paper found in the grate fresh
in my mind, the possibility of a will   (a document almost certain to
contain that word)   occurred to me at once. This possibility was
confirmed by a further circumstance. In the general confusion, the
boudoir had not been swept that morning, and near the desk were several
traces of brown mould and earth. The weather had been perfectly fine
for some days, and no ordinary boots would have left such a heavy
deposit.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
['I strolled to the window, and saw at once that the begonia beds had
been newly planted. The mould in the beds was exactly similar to that
on the floor of the boudoir, and also I learnt from you that they _had_
been planted yesterday afternoon. I was now sure that one, or possibly
both of the gardeners   for there were two sets of footprints in the
bed   had entered the boudoir, for if Mrs. Inglethorp had merely wished
to speak to them she would in all probability have stood at the window,
and they would not have come into the room at all. I was now quite
convinced that she had made a fresh will, and had called the two
gardeners in to witness her signature. Events proved that I was right
in my supposition.']
qText:
I strolled to the window, and saw at once that the begonia beds had
been newly planted. The mould in the beds was exactly similar to that
on the floor of the boudoir, and also I learnt from you that they _had_
been planted yesterday afternoon. I was now sure that one, or possibly
both of the gardeners   for there were two sets of footprints in the
bed   had entered the boudoir, for if Mrs. Inglethorp had merely wished
to speak to them she would in all probability have stood at the window,
and they would not have come into the room at all. I was now quite
convinced that she had made a fresh will, and had called the two
gardeners in to witness her signature. Events proved that I was right
in my supposition.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['That was very ingenious,', 'I must confess\nthat the conclusions I drew from those few scribbled words were quite\nerroneous.']
qText:
That was very ingenious, I must confess
that the conclusions I drew from those few scribbled words were quite
erroneous.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['You gave too much rein to your imagination. Imagination is a good\nservant, and a bad master. The simplest explanation is always the most\nlikely.']
qText:
You gave too much rein to your imagination. Imagination is a good
servant, and a bad master. The simplest explanation is always the most
likely.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Another point   how did you know that the key of the despatch-case had\nbeen lost?']
qText:
Another point   how did you know that the key of the despatch-case had
been lost?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr:
['I did not know it. It was a guess that turned out to be correct. You
observed that it had a piece of twisted wire through the handle. That
suggested to me at once that it had possibly been wrenched off a flimsy
key-ring. Now, if it had been lost and recovered, Mrs. Inglethorp would
at once have replaced it on her bunch; but on her bunch I found what
was obviously the duplicate key, very new and bright, which led me to
the hypothesis that somebody else had inserted the original key in the
lock of the despatch-case.']
qText:
I did not know it. It was a guess that turned out to be correct. You
observed that it had a piece of twisted wire through the handle. That
suggested to me at once that it had possibly been wrenched off a flimsy
key-ring. Now, if it had been lost and recovered, Mrs. Inglethorp would
at once have replaced it on her bunch; but on her bunch I found what
was obviously the duplicate key, very new and bright, which led me to
the hypothesis that somebody else had inserted the original key in the
lock of the despatch-case.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'Alfred Inglethorp, without doubt.']
qText: Yes, Alfred Inglethorp, without doubt.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['You are very sure of his guilt?']
qText: You are very sure of his guilt?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Well, naturally. Every fresh circumstance seems to establish it more\nclearly.']
qText:
Well, naturally. Every fresh circumstance seems to establish it more
clearly.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['On the contrary,', 'there are several points in\nhis favour.']
qText:
On the contrary, there are several points in
his favour.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Oh, come now!']
qText: Oh, come now!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: Yes.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['I see only one.']
qText: I see only one.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['And that?']
qText: And that?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['That he was not in the house last night.']
qText: That he was not in the house last night.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ["Bad shot!' as you English say! You have chosen the one point that to\nmy mind tells against him."]
qText:
Bad shot!' as you English say! You have chosen the one point that to
my mind tells against him.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['How is that?']
qText: How is that?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr:
['Because if Mr. Inglethorp knew that his wife would be poisoned last
night, he would certainly have arranged to be away from the house. His
excuse was an obviously trumped up one. That leaves us two
possibilities: either he knew what was going to happen or he had a
reason of his own for his absence.']
qText:
Because if Mr. Inglethorp knew that his wife would be poisoned last
night, he would certainly have arranged to be away from the house. His
excuse was an obviously trumped up one. That leaves us two
possibilities: either he knew what was going to happen or he had a
reason of his own for his absence.
speaker: Hercule Poirot
menEnts: [[['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Mrs. Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp'], ['Alfred Inglethorp']]]

qTextArr: ['And that reason?']
qText: And that reason?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['How should I know? Discreditable, without doubt. This Mr. Inglethorp,\nI should say, is somewhat of a scoundrel   but that does not of necessity\nmake him a murderer.']
qText:
How should I know? Discreditable, without doubt. This Mr. Inglethorp,
I should say, is somewhat of a scoundrel   but that does not of necessity
make him a murderer.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
['We do not agree, eh?', 'Well, let us leave it. Time will
show which of us is right. Now let us turn to other aspects of the
case. What do you make of the fact that all the doors of the bedroom
were bolted on the inside?']
qText:
We do not agree, eh? Well, let us leave it. Time will
show which of us is right. Now let us turn to other aspects of the
case. What do you make of the fact that all the doors of the bedroom
were bolted on the inside?
speaker: Hercule Poirot
menEnts: [[['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot']], [['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings', 'Hercule Poirot'], ['Mr. Hastings']]]

qTextArr: ['Well', 'One must look at it logically.']
qText: Well One must look at it logically.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['True.']
qText: True.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
['I should put it this way. The doors _were_ bolted   our own eyes have
told us that   yet the presence of the candle grease on the floor, and
the destruction of the will, prove that during the night someone
entered the room. You agree so far?']
qText:
I should put it this way. The doors _were_ bolted   our own eyes have
told us that   yet the presence of the candle grease on the floor, and
the destruction of the will, prove that during the night someone
entered the room. You agree so far?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['Perfectly. Put with admirable clearness. Proceed.']
qText: Perfectly. Put with admirable clearness. Proceed.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
['Well,', 'as the person who entered did not do so by
the window, nor by miraculous means, it follows that the door must have
been opened from inside by Mrs. Inglethorp herself. That strengthens
the conviction that the person in question was her husband. She would
naturally open the door to her own husband.']
qText:
Well, as the person who entered did not do so by
the window, nor by miraculous means, it follows that the door must have
been opened from inside by Mrs. Inglethorp herself. That strengthens
the conviction that the person in question was her husband. She would
naturally open the door to her own husband.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['Why should she? She had bolted the door leading into his room   a most\nunusual proceeding on her part   she had had a most violent quarrel with\nhim that very afternoon. No, he was the last person she would admit.']
qText:
Why should she? She had bolted the door leading into his room   a most
unusual proceeding on her part   she had had a most violent quarrel with
him that very afternoon. No, he was the last person she would admit.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['But you agree with me that the door must have been opened by Mrs.\nInglethorp herself?']
qText:
But you agree with me that the door must have been opened by Mrs.
Inglethorp herself?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['There is another possibility. She may have forgotten to bolt the door\ninto the passage when she went to bed, and have got up later, towards\nmorning, and bolted it then.']
qText:
There is another possibility. She may have forgotten to bolt the door
into the passage when she went to bed, and have got up later, towards
morning, and bolted it then.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Poirot, is that seriously your opinion?']
qText: Poirot, is that seriously your opinion?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['No, I do not say it is so, but it might be. Now, to turn to another\nfeature, what do you make of the scrap of conversation you overheard\nbetween Mrs. Cavendish and her mother-in-law?']
qText:
No, I do not say it is so, but it might be. Now, to turn to another
feature, what do you make of the scrap of conversation you overheard
between Mrs. Cavendish and her mother-in-law?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr:
['I had forgotten that,', 'That is as enigmatical as
ever. It seems incredible that a woman like Mrs. Cavendish, proud and
reticent to the last degree, should interfere so violently in what was
certainly not her affair.']
qText:
I had forgotten that, That is as enigmatical as
ever. It seems incredible that a woman like Mrs. Cavendish, proud and
reticent to the last degree, should interfere so violently in what was
certainly not her affair.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['Precisely. It was an astonishing thing for a woman of her breeding to\ndo.']
qText:
Precisely. It was an astonishing thing for a woman of her breeding to
do.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['It is certainly curious,', 'Still, it is unimportant, and\nneed not be taken into account.']
qText:
It is certainly curious, Still, it is unimportant, and
need not be taken into account.
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['What have I always told you? Everything must be taken into account. If\nthe fact will not fit the theory   let the theory go.']
qText:
What have I always told you? Everything must be taken into account. If
the fact will not fit the theory   let the theory go.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: Well, we shall see,
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['Yes, we shall see.']
qText: Yes, we shall see.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Look, Poirot!']
qText: Look, Poirot!
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['_Tiens!_', "It is Mr. Mace, from the chemist's shop. He is\ncoming here."]
qText:
_Tiens!_ It is Mr. Mace, from the chemist's shop. He is
coming here.

qTextArr: ['A little minute,', 'I come.']
qText: A little minute, I come.

qText:
Oh, Mr. Poirot, I'm sorry for the inconvenience, but I heard that

qTextArr: ['Yes, we have.']
qText: Yes, we have.

It's all over the village about old Mrs. Inglethorp dying so suddenly.
They do say

qTextArr: ["that it's poison?"]
qText: that it's poison?

qText: Yes, exactly   of course

Yes, He will have evidence to give at the

qTextArr: ['Not now, not now, _mon ami_. I have need of reflection. My mind is in\nsome disorder   which is not well.']

Not now, not now, _mon ami_. I have need of reflection. My mind is in

qTextArr:
['It is well. The bad moment has passed. Now all is arranged and
classified. One must never permit confusion. The case is not clear
yet   no. For it is of the most complicated! It puzzles _me_. _Me_,

qText:
It is well. The bad moment has passed. Now all is arranged and
classified. One must never permit confusion. The case is not clear
yet   no. For it is of the most complicated! It puzzles _me_. _Me_,
Hercule Poirot! There are two facts of significance.

qTextArr: ['And what are they?']
qText: And what are they?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr: ['The first is the state of the weather yesterday. That is very\nimportant.']
qText:
The first is the state of the weather yesterday. That is very
important.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['But it was a glorious day!', "Poirot, you're pulling my\nleg!"]

But it was a glorious day! Poirot, you're pulling my

qTextArr: ['Not at all. The thermometer registered 80 degrees in the shade. Do not\nforget that, my friend. It is the key to the whole riddle!']

Not at all. The thermometer registered 80 degrees in the shade. Do not
forget that, my friend. It is the key to the whole riddle!

qText: And the second point?

The important fact that Monsieur Inglethorp wears very peculiar

qTextArr: ["And supposing the Coroner's jury returns a verdict of Wilful Murder\nagainst Alfred Inglethorp. What becomes of your theories, then?"]
qText:
And supposing the Coroner's jury returns a verdict of Wilful Murder
against Alfred Inglethorp. What becomes of your theories, then?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qTextArr:
['They would not be shaken because twelve stupid men had happened to
make a mistake! But that will not occur. For one thing, a country jury
is not anxious to take responsibility upon itself, and Mr. Inglethorp
stands practically in the position of local squire. Also,', '_I_ should not allow it!']
qText:
They would not be shaken because twelve stupid men had happened to
make a mistake! But that will not occur. For one thing, a country jury
is not anxious to take responsibility upon itself, and Mr. Inglethorp
stands practically in the position of local squire. Also, _I_ should not allow it!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['_You_ would not allow it?']
qText: _You_ would not allow it?
speaker: Mr. Hastings

qText: No.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['Oh, yes, _mon ami_, I would do what I say.']
qText: Oh, yes, _mon ami_, I would do what I say.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qTextArr: ['In all this, you see, I think of that poor Mrs.\nInglethorp who is dead. She was not extravagantly loved   no. But she was\nvery good to us Belgians   I owe her a debt.']
qText:
In all this, you see, I think of that poor Mrs.
Inglethorp who is dead. She was not extravagantly loved   no. But she was
very good to us Belgians   I owe her a debt.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

qText: You'm from the Hall, bain't you?

qText:
Yes. I'm looking for a friend of mine whom I thought might have walked
this way.

qTextArr: ['Is it possible that she could have swallowed the poison by accident?']
qText: Is it possible that she could have swallowed the poison by accident?

qTextArr: ['I should consider it very unlikely. Strychnine is not used for\ndomestic purposes, as some poisons are, and there are restrictions\nplaced on its sale.']
qText:

Does anything in your examination lead you to determine how the poison

qTextArr: ["I entered Mrs. Inglethorp's room. She was at that moment in a typical\ntetanic convulsion. She turned towards me, and gasped out:"]
qText:
I entered Mrs. Inglethorp's room. She was at that moment in a typical
tetanic convulsion. She turned towards me, and gasped out:
